question: If a PI anticipates that cost sharing commitments will not be met, what actions are required according to the document?
answer: If it appears that cost sharing commitments will not be met, the PI shall notify the ORS Contracts & Grants Specialist and contact the funding agency to obtain prior approval for modification to the approved cost sharing amount or determine corrective action to be taken to become compliant.

question: What is the purpose of the National Student Exchange Program (NSE) as outlined in Executive Policy 7.201?
answer: The purpose of the National Student Exchange Program (NSE) is "To provide University of Hawai‘i students with the opportunity to enroll at member institutions in other areas of the United States through exchange placements involving reduced tuition and fees," and "To operate the program on a partially self-supporting basis through the collection of participant application/placement fees."

question: What are the two plans (Plan A and Plan B) available for reduced tuition and fees for incoming and outgoing NSE students?
answer: Plan A permits payment of resident (in-state/in-province) tuition and fees at the institution the student attends while on exchange.  Plan B permits payment of tuition and fees at the student’s home institution, under the condition that incoming students accepted under this plan be granted tuition exemption.

question: When was the University of Hawai‘i's participation in the NSE approved by the Board of Regents?
answer: The Board of Regents approved the University of Hawai‘i's participation in the NSE on July 27, 1978.

question: What is the role of the Chancellor for each campus in managing the campus NSE program?
answer: The Chancellor for each campus is responsible for "overseeing the management of the campus NSE program, in conformance with these policies and procedures" (III.B.8).  Authority to oversee and manage the campus NSE program is delegated to chancellors (IV. Delegation of Authority).

question: Besides the per-student application/placement fee due to the NSE Central Office, what other expenses can the application/placement fee revenue be used for?
answer: In addition to the per-student application/placement fee due to the NSE Central Office, revenue may be used to pay "the institutional membership fees, expenses for each campus NSE Coordinator to attend the mandatory NSE annual placement conference, and partial additional campus program expenses".

question: What is the effective date of Executive Policy 11.203, and what are the dates it was amended?
answer: The effective date of Executive Policy 11.203 is October 2014.  It was amended on September 2005 and September 2020.

question: According to section II, Definitions, what constitutes "Philanthropic naming"?
answer: “Philanthropic naming” is an act that purposefully designates a name or title for a facility, property, or program in order to honor or recognize a significant donor to the university whether a person, family, or other entity.

question: What level of approval is required to name a non-degree-granting Center, Institute, or program, according to the provided matrix?
answer: To name a non-degree-granting Center, Institute, or program requires approval from the Campus CEO and the President.

question: Under what conditions might the President seek advice from the Regents regarding an honorific naming?
answer: The President shall seek the advice of the Regents if the individual to be honorifically recognized is living or it is within five years of the person’s death.  "In cases where the individual to be honorifically recognized is living or it is within five years of the person’s death, the President shall seek the advice of the Regents, who shall evaluate the nomination and provide the President their counsel regarding the nomination."

question: What office is responsible for this policy and how can they be contacted?
answer: The Office of the Vice President for Administration is responsible for this policy.  They can be contacted at (808) 956-6405 or vpadmin@hawaii.edu.

question: What is the effective date of Board of Regents Policy 3.201?
answer: The effective date of Board of Regents Policy 3.201 is September 27, 2007.  The document also states that it was "Prior Dates Amended: Oct. 20, 1978; Nov. 15, 1985; March 17, 1989; July 20, 1990; Jan. 19, 2001; Oct. 31, 2014 (recodified)."

question: When was the last time Board of Regents Policy 3.201 was reviewed?
answer: The document states that the review date was August 2017.

question: According to section III, what entities constitute the major organizational units of the University of Hawai‘i system?
answer: According to section III, the major organizational units of the University of Hawai‘i are: the University of Hawai‘i System; University of Hawai‘i at Mānoa; University of Hawai‘i at Hilo; University of Hawai‘i - West O‘ahu; and University of Hawai‘i Community Colleges (including Honolulu Community College, Kapi‘olani Community College, Leeward Community College, Windward Community College, Kaua‘i Community College, UH Maui College, and Hawai‘i Community College).

question: What contact information is provided for inquiries regarding this policy?
answer: The document provides the following contact information:  "Office of the Board of Regents, 956-8213, bor@hawaii.edu"

question: What year was the 1977 edition of the Faculty Handbook published?
answer: The document states that the "1977 Edition of the Faculty Handbook" is a  "1973 Interim Revision".

question: Which parts of the Faculty Handbook have been incorporated into the collective bargaining agreement for Unit 7 faculty?
answer: Part 4, Conditions of Service, and Appendices H, I, and T of the Faculty Handbook have been incorporated into the collective bargaining agreement for Unit 7 faculty.

question: What is the purpose of incorporating the Faculty Handbook into the Administrative Procedures Manual?
answer: To incorporate the Faculty Handbook as part of the Administrative Procedures Manual for immediate reference and guidance.

question: Does this administrative procedure apply to all University of Hawaii employees?
answer: Yes, the document states that "The Faculty Handbook applies to the faculty and staff of the University of Hawaii."

question: Besides Part 4 and Appendices H, I, and T, what other sections of the Faculty Handbook are included in the collective bargaining agreement?
answer: The document states that "Parts 1, 2, 3 and Appendices E, F, G, J, K, P and R have not been incorporated into the collective bargaining agreement."  Therefore, no other sections besides Part 4 and Appendices H, I, and T are included in the collective bargaining agreement.

question: What is the effective date of Administrative Procedure 9.025?
answer: The effective date of Administrative Procedure 9.025 is March 2024.

question: According to section III.3.1, under what circumstance might an employee be denied access to their personal record?
answer: According to section III.3.1, an employee may be denied access to their record if they are unable to produce verification of identity, or if access is denied according to section 92F-22, Hawai‘i Revised Statutes.

question: If an employee requests a copy of their personal record, what costs might they incur, and who determines these costs?
answer: The document states that "At the discretion of the Designee for Personal Records, employees may be charged for any copies and for certification of copies. The cost shall include the cost of duplication, transcription of the record, if necessary, and any search required to find the records involved."  The Designee for Personal Records determines these costs.

question: How many working days does the Designee for Personal Records have to respond to a request for correction or amendment of a personal record?
answer: The Designee for Personal Records has twenty (20) working days after receipt of the request to acknowledge receipt and either make the requested correction or amendment, or inform the employee in writing of their refusal, the reason for refusal, and the University procedures for review of the refusal.  "Within twenty (20) working days after receipt of the request, the designee for personal records shall acknowledge receipt of the request in writing and promptly: (1) Make the requested correction or amendment; or (2) Inform the employee in writing of their refusal to correct or amend the personal record, the reason for refusal, and the University procedures for review of the refusal."

question: What governing boards or executive policies does Administrative Procedure 9.025 reference?
answer: Administrative Procedure 9.025 references Executive Policy Chapter 9, EP 9.175, and Executive Policy Chapter 2, EP 2.216.

question: What is the purpose of Administrative Procedure No. A9.030?
answer: The purpose of Administrative Procedure No. A9.030 is "To promulgate a procedure for complying with federal and State laws on posting employment related notices" and "To inform employees of federal and State employment laws and regulations."

question: Which website should be used to download federally required employment posters?
answer: All federally required posters may be downloaded from the United States Department of Labor website.

question: Who is responsible for selecting and maintaining locations for posted employment notices at each work site?
answer: Deans and Directors are responsible for "selecting, monitoring, and maintaining locations, which are readily accessible to employees," for posting employment notices at each work site.

question: Besides the federal requirements, how many different State-required notices are listed in Attachment 1 of this document?
answer: Attachment 1 lists eight State-required notices.

question: What specific federal law(s) are referenced under the "Federal Notices" section of Attachment 1?
answer: The "Federal Notices" section of Attachment 1 references the following federal laws: Civil Rights Act of 1964 (Title VI and VII), Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, Equal Pay Act of 1963, Executive Order 11246, Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Sections 503 and 504), Vietnam Era Veterans Readjustment Act of 1974 (Section 402), Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, Fair Labor Standards Act, Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993, and Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act.

question: What is the purpose of Executive Policy 8.201?
answer: The purpose of Executive Policy 8.201 is "To plan, manage and control the collection of revenues and the disbursements of funds so as to maximize the pool of temporarily idle cash," and "To invest available idle cash to maximize yields while maintaining adequate security and liquidity in investments permitted under Hawai‘i Revised Statutes §36-21, short term investment of state moneys."

question: Which office is responsible for managing the short-term investments of operating funds?
answer: The Treasury Office invests idle cash from all operating funds.  "Idle cash from all operating funds shall be pooled and invested by the Treasury Office."

question: What is the effective date of Executive Policy 8.201, and when was it last reviewed?
answer: The effective date of Executive Policy 8.201 is October 2014.  It was last reviewed in August 2018.

question: According to the policy, where must short-term investments of operating funds be made?
answer: Short-term investments of operating funds shall be made in accordance with HRS 36-21.

question: What is the procedure for allocating interest earned from short-term investments of idle cash?
answer: Interest earned shall be prorated based on average daily cash balances (Section III, E).
